items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: PM backs away from Matildas public holiday push. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Stephanie Borys Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is backing away from his push for a public holiday if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup. The final decision rests with state and territory leaders, and while some are on board with the idea, others aren't convinced due to the costs on small businesses. Albanese had previously declared the matter would be discussed at today's national cabinet meeting. But speaking on Triple M Hobart, he now says that's not the case. "We won't actually be discussing it today, we are discussing housing and other issues," he says. "It's up to the states and territories what they do. But when the public holiday was held for the memorial day for the Queen, what happened was that a whole range of small businesses went gang busters on that day." Yesterday, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton called the PM's push for a public holiday a "stunt" and an "ego trip" .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM backs down from Matildas public holiday discussions

children.content: By political reporter Stephanie Borys
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is backing away from his push for a public holiday if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup.
The final decision rests with state and territory leaders, and while some are on board with the idea, others aren't convinced due to the costs on small businesses.
Albanese had previously declared the matter would be discussed at today's national cabinet meeting. But speaking on Triple M Hobart, he now says that's not the case.
"We won't actually be discussing it today, we are discussing housing and other issues," he says.

"It's up to the states and territories what they do. But when the public holiday was held for the memorial day for the Queen, what happened was that a whole range of small businesses went gang busters on that day."
Yesterday, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
called the PM's push for a public holiday a "stunt" and an "ego trip"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea has claimed a US soldier who bolted into the North across the Korean border last month did so after being "disillusioned at the inequality of American society". Private 2nd Class Travis King entered North Korea while on a tour of the Joint Security Area on the heavily fortified border between the two Koreas, becoming the first American detained in the North in nearly five years. The North's official Korean Central News Agency said King told investigators he had decided to enter North Korea because he "harbored ill feeling against inhuman maltreatment and racial discrimination within the US Army". The Pentagon on Tuesday said it could not verify alleged comments made by King that North Korean state media reported, but that Washington remained focused on his safe return. "The department's priority is to bring Private King home, and that we are working through all available channels to achieve that outcome," a Pentagon spokesperson said. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea claims detained US soldier 'disillusioned at the inequality of American society'

featuredLink.title: North Korea claims American soldier defected because of 'inhuman maltreatment and racial discrimination in US Army'

props.alt: A photo of Travis King. He is a black man  in his 20s with dark eyes.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The national anti-scam centre is warning fraudsters are targeting fans on social media, offering fake ticket sales and fake live-stream links to matches. The consumer watchdog, the ACCC, is reminding consumers to only buy from authorised ticket sellers, and to double-check a streaming site before entering any payment details to watch the game. "We are already seeing initial reports of scam activity, particularly on Facebook, where scammers are responding to posts from people looking for tickets and using compromised accounts to sell non-existent tickets," ACCC deputy chair Catriona Lowe says. "There have also been reports of scammers claiming there is a problem with the payment and asking for it to be made again."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas fans are being urged to be wary of scammers ahead of tonight's game

children.content: The national anti-scam centre is warning fraudsters are targeting fans on social media, offering fake ticket sales and fake live-stream links to matches.
The consumer watchdog, the ACCC, is reminding consumers to
only buy from authorised ticket sellers, and to double-check a streaming site before entering any payment details
to watch the game.

"We are already seeing initial reports of scam activity, particularly on Facebook, where scammers are responding to posts from people looking for tickets and using compromised accounts to sell non-existent tickets," ACCC deputy chair Catriona Lowe says.
"There have also been reports of scammers claiming there is a problem with the payment and asking for it to be made again."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While residential real estate may have been on the bounce over the past five or six months, rising interest rates have made property a bad sector to be in over the past year. Developer and landlord Mirvac has swung to a $165 million loss in financial year 2023, down from a $906 million profit the year before. The loss has been driven by write-downs in the value of its office (-5.6 per cent ) and retail (-5.3 per cent ) property portfolios, partly offset by a +6.2 per cent revaluation of its industrial properties. The company also sold off about $500 million of "non-core" assets at a 2 per cent discount to their book values, excluding the cost of the sales. Mirvac said it would continue to increase its exposure to residential and industrial real estate, while reducing the share of office space on its books, as the persistence of working from home dents demand in that sector. Excluding one-off costs, the company's "operating profit" dropped 3 per cent to $580 million. It will pay a 5.3 cent per share final dividend .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mirvac highlights that property was not the place to be over the past year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator has told insurers to lift their game when it comes to claims handling. A review by ASIC has found that general insurers can, and should, improve their claims handling processes and dedicate more resources, after identifying a number of weaknesses. "An insurance claim doesn’t have to be handled perfectly, but it must be handled well," ASIC deputy chair Karen Chester said. "Our claims handling review found good practices and poor practices across all six insurers. "We identified five areas where insurers can and should make immediate claims handling improvements — consumer communications, project management, identifying vulnerable consumers and complaints, resourcing of claims and complaints handling." The report was based on data from more than 200,000 claims lodged in the first three months of last year. Insurers included in the review included Suncorp, AAMI, Allianz, Budget Direct, QBE, IAG and Youi. Consumer advocates have welcomed the findings. "The insurance process can be stressful, especially in the wake of the extreme weather events that are happening more often, and I am delighted ASIC is telling insurers they must lift their game especially for people who are vulnerable," Consumer Action Law Centre managing lawyer Philippa Heir said. You can listen to a report from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Do better, corporate regulator tells insurers

said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Anyone who drives over a toll road regularly is unlikely to be surprised by the fact the Transurban has seen a massive jump in its profit. The company has reported a more than tripling in net profit from a year ago, to $64 million. Its revenue jumped 22 per cent to about $4.16 billion. Toll revenue lifted across the areas it operates: Sydney +31.9 per cent Melbourne +23.8 per cent Brisbane +15.5 per cent North America +22 per cent And while more cars on the roads are not good news for your commute, it's great news for Transubran. Transurban says it saw record traffic across its roads over the 2023 financial year, with a record 2.4 million trips, and it has more projects nearing completion, including Sydney's Rozelle Interchange and more roads that will connect into WestConnex. And it expects more "traffic growth" in the year ahead due to forecast population growth in its major markets — Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and the greater Washington area in the US. The company will pay a final dividend of 31.5 cents per share, taking its full-year payout to 58 cents, up 40 per cent. And it's already touting an increased payout for the current financial year, as it plans to hand back cash from WestConnex that it previously held onto during the construction — it expects an FY24 distribution of 62 cents per share, up 7 per cent. In other news out this morning from the toll road operator, current chief financial officer Michelle Jablko will take over the top job from mid-October. Ms Jablko joined the company in early 2021 and will take the helm from Scott Charlton, who has been running Transurban for more than a decade. The company says a new CFO will be announced in "due course".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Transurban profit skyrockets, new boss announced
